results.title: Dance me to my song
results.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer, Domenico Procacci, Giuseppe Pedersoli, Fandango, Intra Films, Smile Productions and Vertigo Productions
results.brief_description: de Heer’s seventh feature addresses issues of obligation, accountability, need and love, through the conflicted relationship between a severely physically disabled young woman, Julia, and her abusive, short-tempered and lonely carer, Madelaine. Like Heather Rose, the actor inflicted with cerebral palsy that plays her, Julia is confined to a wheelchair and is able to communicate only through a voice-synthesizer. Nevertheless, much to Madelaine’s chagrin, she succeeds in developing a close friendship with Eddie, a man she meets on the street. But Julia wants love and sex, not just companionship, and the two women become locked in a battle for Eddie’s attentions. Rose’s participation in the film, both as its lead and as a co-writer, and the unflinching focus on the minutiae of her labourous and painful daily routine, brings it into the realm of documentary. As in his earlier films ‘Bad Boy Bubby’ and ‘The Quiet Room’, de Heer again focuses on a central character who succeeds in battling against totally inconceivable odds to overcome their victimhood. Cast includes: Heather Rose, Joey Kennedy, John Brumpton, Rena Owen.

results.title: Dance crazy in Hollywood
results.creator_credit: Robert Kuperberg, Gerard Paquet, Clara Films and RM Arts
results.brief_description: A collection of cinematic excerpts along with interviews with Hermes Pan, choreographer extraordinaire who created many of the most memorable musical dance moments in the era of the major Hollywood musicals. The film is a biographical study of Pan’s entry into the world of dance, his arrival in Hollywood, and his work with a variety of filmmakers, actors and dancers. Ultimately, it is also a tribute to his contribution to musical film history as the documentary was completed very shortly before his death. Also featuring discussion about and footage of dance greats such as Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers, Rita Hayworth, Kim Novak, Bob Fosse, Ann Miller, Carol Haney, Elizabeth Taylor, Cyd Charisse and Hermes Pan himself in rare motion picture appearances, the documentary is a personalised insight into the Hollywood musical era with reflective commentary from Pan in the presentation of its archival contents.

results.title: Mondo Lugosi: a vampire's scrapbook
results.brief_description: A compilation of movie trailers and excerpts from many of Bela Lugosi’s horror films dating from the 1930s to the late 1940s. Born Bela Ferenc Dezso Blasko on 20 October 1882 in Lugos, Hungary, Lugosi began his acting career on stage performing with the Budapest Academy of Theatrical Arts and as a leading actor with Hungary’s Royal National Theatre. By 1920 Lugosi had moved across to Germany where he began appearing in films. He emigrated to America in 1921 playing bit parts in obscure films until finally in 1931 he broke into the Hollywood scene, cast in the title role of the horror film, “Dracula”. Numerous other films of similar genre followed, including “Murders in the Rue Morgue” (1932), “The Invisible ray” (1936), “The Wolf man” (1941), “The Ghost of Frankenstein” (1942), “Frankenstein meets the Wolf Man” (1942) and “The Body snatcher” (1945). Trailers of these films, along with interviews and appearances by Lugosi on American television programs “Tribute to a star” and “You asked for it” are contained in this video. Includes scenes with Boris Karloff, Frances Drake, Claude Rains, Betty Boop and many other stars of the time.

results.title: Jamboree for friendship
results.brief_description: Boy Scouts from one hundred countries take part in the varied activities at the Twelfth Boy Scout Jamboree in Idaho, summer 1967. Youths swap talk and ideas, show each other crafts, national dances and customs, attend religious services, take part in a rodeo and a spectacular night campfire - making friends from around the world.

results.title: Jake: today I became a man
results.brief_description: Jake is an extraordinary child who just so happens to love dressing up and performing. His resolution to be himself and carve out an identity for himself regardless of societal expectations is inspiring. A remarkable story told in Jake’s language in which he articulately discusses growing up and his love of singing and performing in drag. An eye opening piece which challenges assumptions of personal identity and that kids do understand themselves and their ‘place’ in the world.

results.title: Jagged edge
results.creator_credit: Richard Marquand, Martin Ransohoff and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: A well-crafted, hardboiled mystery with sharp perfromances by murder suspect Jeff Bridges and tough-but-smitten defense attorney Glenn Close. The murder victim was a socialite and heiress. Her husband (James Bridges), an upwardly mobile newspaper publisher, now owns his wife’s fortune. Embittered by past experiences with criminal law, Close is pressed to defend Bridges, once he convinces her of his innocence. This movie raises jagged questions about an imperfect justice system and will leave you guessing until the very end - did he or didn’t he? Robert Loggia received a 1985 Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor.
